comments:
Build ID: I20070621-1340

Steps To Reproduce:
1. Create new Java project
2. Create /web/WEB-INF/ folder
3. Put two files into /web:

file1.jsp:
(empty)

file2.jsp:
<%@ include file="/file1.jsp" %>
<%
// content assist doesn't work here
%>

4. Try to use content assist in file2.jsp in between the <% %> tags. This results in a 'Content Assist not available at the current location'. Using a relative reference (<%@ include file="file1.jsp" %>) works fine, however.

More information:
I'm using a normal Java project instead of a Dynamic Web Project because I'm using the Sysdeo Tomcat Plugin. This used to work under Calisto release, but has stopped working under Europa.

In addition to this, the following exception shows up in the Eclipse log:

Just wanted to comment that using the JSP editor in a Java project is a supported scenario, so this should work.

It appears that the WPE is registering a URIResolver that trumps the default ProjectResolver normally used by JSPTranslator.  This resolver assumes that anything in a "/" root is relative to a web root.

A couple of work-arounds:

1) Disable the Web Page Editor feature. This will of course mean you can't use that feature but the JSP editor should return to normal.  You will need to restart Eclipse.

2) Use relative rather than absolute include paths if practical.  If you remove the leading "/" from your include, things should work.

We also have another outstanding bug fix at HEAD that may mitigate this:

https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=199304



--Cam

Tried to disable the web page editor (WTP Web Page Editor) plugin, but the problem persists. I can't really stop using absolute paths as including a page fragment that has a relative path doesn't work all the time.

(In reply to comment #4)
> Tried to disable the web page editor (WTP Web Page Editor) plugin, but the
> problem persists. I can't really stop using absolute paths as including a page
> fragment that has a relative path doesn't work all the time.

When I disable the Web Page Editor:

1) Disable WTP Web Page Editor *and* SDK for Web Page Editor 1.0.0.qualifier (if present).

2) Close any source projects related to jst.pagedesigner in your workspace (if present).

3) Restart Eclipse.

Then I get the exception below for your test case which is slightly different and appears to be generated by the JSP editor framework rather than JSF.  It seems to hint at the fact that when you're in a non-web project, then the project root is considered the web root.  Indeed, if you change your include to "/web/test1.jsp" you content assist should work.

Could you verify?

Something else I noticed that is interesting is that even though content assist seems to be fixed "/web/test.jsp", it is flagged by a validation warning saying the file is not found at "/TestProject/web/web/test1.jsp".

Nitin, are you sure this use case is well supported?

<snip>

I disabled WTP web page editor (couldn't find anything about WPE SDK, so I guess I don't have it) and closed all projects. Restarted eclipse, but the problem still occurred.

And yeah using a path relative to the project root (instead of web root) does work. But obviously moving all the web files to the project's root isn't practival. The odd thing is that when using the project root, content assist works but I get a warning in the include saying that the file can't be found :)

-Mathieu

(In reply to comment #6)
> Something else I noticed that is interesting is that even though content assist
> seems to be fixed "/web/test.jsp", it is flagged by a validation warning saying
> the file is not found at "/TestProject/web/web/test1.jsp".

I'm not sure what that first sentence means.  As for the validation message, the validator is assuming that the parent of the WEB-INF folder is the "root", such as in Mathieu's original comment, and expecting to find that file1.jsp is located there.  It's an oversight that the JSP translator is using the resolvers, but the result is supposed to be the same if possible.  Cameron, do you somehow have an extra /TestProject/web/web/WEB-INF folder not mentioned in comment 0?

> Nitin, are you sure this use case is well supported?

It's not a *primary* use case, no, but since the JSP component tries to avoid hard ties to our server launch and flexible layout infrastructure, we've tried to support plain Java Projects since day one--at least as long as the necessary Servlet jars are on the Java Build Path.


Anyway, I suggest this bug be used to address the NPE in WebrootUtil.  The JSP component's own problems fall under bug 196020, which is already set for 2.0.1.

I appears that we won't have time to fix this in 2.0.1.  With Nitin's fix, the workaround of disabling the WPE features should ensure that the JSP editor can be used in a non-web project.

Deferring target to 3.0.
Checking ModuleCoreNature.isFlexibleProject(project) in  org.eclipse.jst.pagedesigner.utils.UriAdapterFactory.getAdapter(Object, Class) might allow you to correctly guard against the original NPE.
Appears to be fixed in WST 2.0.1. Hurray!

traces.message: Path must include project and resource name: /test1.jsp
